GOD.content: a look, God’s look, God’s gaze, that cannot be exchanged, situates original sin, is the essence of responsibility [p. 91 not Kantian autonomy, freedom]
GOD.linkedContent: a look, God’s look, God’s gaze, that cannot be exchanged, situates original sin, is the essence of responsibility [p. 91 not Kantian autonomy, freedom]

GT.content: “freedom” in Kant’s speculative philosophy [?] can’t be demonstrated, it’s a “letter of credit for the moral law,” an assumption; also that (diabolical) evil can never be a motive
GT.linkedContent: “freedom” in Kant’s speculative philosophy [?] can’t be demonstrated, it’s a “letter of credit for the moral law,” an assumption; also that (diabolical) evil can never be a motive

GT.content: faith/belief (act of faith/credit) given w/ monetary language, practical reason cannot be separated from chremastics as we interpreted it above
GT.linkedContent: faith/belief (act of faith/credit) given w/ monetary language, practical reason cannot be separated from chremastics as we interpreted it above

FK.content: via Kant’s moral law, Christianity can only answer its moral calling in death of God far beyond figures of the Passion
FK.linkedContent: via Kant’s moral law, Christianity can only answer its moral calling in death of God far beyond figures of the Passion

FK.content: via Kant’s “formal rigor,” a law that programs an infinite spiral of outbidding; today both “fundamentalisms” & “integrisms” hyperbolize this outbidding
FK.linkedContent: via Kant’s “formal rigor,” a law that programs an infinite spiral of outbidding; today both “fundamentalisms” & “integrisms” hyperbolize this outbidding

FK.content: w/ Kant, self-sacrifice sacrifices most proper in service of most proper
FK.linkedContent: w/ Kant, self-sacrifice sacrifices most proper in service of most proper

FL.content: apply rule w/out justice, Kant would say, I acted in conformity with duty but not through duty or out of respect for the law (loi)
FL.linkedContent: apply rule w/out justice, Kant would say, I acted in conformity with duty but not through duty or out of respect for the law (loi)

FL.content: Kant’s categorical imperative—uncontestable but “allows for no critique of violence”
FL.linkedContent: Kant’s categorical imperative—uncontestable but “allows for no critique of violence”

BL.content: Kant: typology, symbolic presentation of moral good (beauty, a symbol of morality), respect for law which only appears in law > “as if” in maxim: reconciles practical reason w/ historical teleology (narrative), w/ possibility of unlimited progress
BL.linkedContent: Kant: typology, symbolic presentation of moral good (beauty, a symbol of morality), respect for law which only appears in law > “as if” in maxim: reconciles practical reason w/ historical teleology (narrative), w/ possibility of unlimited progress

BL.content: for Kant, pure morality excludes historicity, empirical narrativity > shelters these parasites
BL.linkedContent: for Kant, pure morality excludes historicity, empirical narrativity > shelters these parasites

BL.content: problem of exemplarity [knowing how to enter into the law] w/ re: to Kant’s respect for the law > the example would be the effect of the law, only summoned before the law
BL.linkedContent: problem of exemplarity [knowing how to enter into the law] w/ re: to Kant’s respect for the law > the example would be the effect of the law, only summoned before the law

BL.content: Kant like Kafka knows the law is an idiom for you—never general
BL.linkedContent: Kant like Kafka knows the law is an idiom for you—never general

H.content: categorical imperative (under erasure) of hospitality, unconditional; p. 83 unconditional w/out imperative, w/out duty, beyond economy and debt
H.linkedContent: categorical imperative (under erasure) of hospitality, unconditional; p. 83 unconditional w/out imperative, w/out duty, beyond economy and debt

POO.content: sacrifice and sacrificial at heart of Kant’s morality
POO.linkedContent: sacrifice and sacrificial at heart of Kant’s morality

POO.content: Kant’s pure law whose concept conforms to no example (no mimesis); p. 141n the idea of moral perfection, which reason formulates apriori and connects, inseparably, to free will > the “true original which lies in reason
POO.linkedContent: Kant’s pure law whose concept conforms to no example (no mimesis); p. 141n the idea of moral perfection, which reason formulates apriori and connects, inseparably, to free will > the “true original which lies in reason

POOF.content: via Kant, responsibility (response, speaking, time) of friendship linked to respect (distance, gaze, space) > Kant links highest friendship to ‘moral law,’ to distance, repulsion, links love to attraction—if it’s a duty to intend toward dignity of ‘sympathy’ & ‘communication (Mitteilung),’ ‘ardour’, excess, of love can break equality while maintaining reciprocity > there must be outward signs, (external) testaments of friendship [?]
POOF.linkedContent: via Kant, responsibility (response, speaking, time) of friendship linked to respect (distance, gaze, space) > Kant links highest friendship to ‘moral law,’ to distance, repulsion, links love to attraction—if it’s a duty to intend toward dignity of ‘sympathy’ & ‘communication (Mitteilung),’ ‘ardour’, excess, of love can break equality while maintaining reciprocity > there must be outward signs, (external) testaments of friendship [?]

POOF.content: for Kant, friendship doesn’t produce happiness, the 2 feelings [in each person?] render mankind worthy of being happy
POOF.linkedContent: for Kant, friendship doesn’t produce happiness, the 2 feelings [in each person?] render mankind worthy of being happy

POOF.content: fraternal friendship & ascension, height: Kant’s stellar sublimity of moral law, Nietzsche’s star friendship
POOF.linkedContent: fraternal friendship & ascension, height: Kant’s stellar sublimity of moral law, Nietzsche’s star friendship

EM.content: Kant’s pure end of moral law—not anthropological

VM.content: Kant and Levinas both have immediate respect for other, but Levinas does not pass through neutral element of universal, nor through respect for law
VM.linkedContent: Kant and Levinas both have immediate respect for other, but Levinas does not pass through neutral element of universal, nor through respect for law

PP.content: dialectical inversion of pharmakon or dangerous supplement makes death à la fois acceptable and null > immortality of soul, acts like antibody, dissipates its terrifying fantasy, le pharmarkon inverti, qui met en fuite tous les épouvantails: origin of epistēmē, opening to truth as possibility of repetition, submission of “greed for life (epithumein zēn)” to law (king, father, capital)
PP.linkedContent: dialectical inversion of pharmakon or dangerous supplement makes death à la fois acceptable and null > immortality of soul, acts like antibody, dissipates its terrifying fantasy, le pharmarkon inverti, qui met en fuite tous les épouvantails: origin of epistēmē, opening to truth as possibility of repetition, submission of “greed for life (epithumein zēn)” to law (king, father, capital)

OH.content: following program—application of know-how > ethics & politics become a technology, no longer order of practical reason or decision, begins to be irresponsible
OH.linkedContent: following program—application of know-how > ethics & politics become a technology, no longer order of practical reason or decision, begins to be irresponsible

OH.content: [threatened] ideality in capitalization: that which exceeds borders of sensible, opens onto infinite, gives rise to universal, “maxim of maximization,” nothing other than spirit itself
OH.linkedContent: [threatened] ideality in capitalization: that which exceeds borders of sensible, opens onto infinite, gives rise to universal, “maxim of maximization,” nothing other than spirit itself

OH.content: the duty to respond to call of European memory, all other duties presuppose this one in silence [?]
OH.linkedContent: the duty to respond to call of European memory, all other duties presuppose this one in silence [?]

OH.content: duty to act in accord w/ a double contradiction that is not simply a Kantian illusionary antimony but an effective one (w/ experience, through experiment), interminable
OH.linkedContent: duty to act in accord w/ a double contradiction that is not simply a Kantian illusionary antimony but an effective one (w/ experience, through experiment), interminable

FWT.content: Kant: (finite) subject of law—subject of duty > save God, who has no duty, and slave, who has duties but no rights [see ATIA pp. 99-100]
FWT.linkedContent: Kant: (finite) subject of law—subject of duty > save God, who has no duty, and slave, who has duties but no rights [see ATIA pp. 99-100]

FWT.content: DP conceived of as heart of all criminal law, all moral law (Kant) > its condition or transcendental
FWT.linkedContent: DP conceived of as heart of all criminal law, all moral law (Kant) > its condition or transcendental

FWT.content: deconstruction of DP makes untenable from w/in distinction btwn internal punishment (poena naturalis) & external (poena forensis): [Kant does Derrida’s work for him] since guilty should sign off on punishment, all executed punishment would be like a suicide > no law immune from interest, revenge, the sacrificial (for Kant, moral/judicial reason is sacrificial)
FWT.linkedContent: deconstruction of DP makes untenable from w/in distinction btwn internal punishment (poena naturalis) & external (poena forensis): [Kant does Derrida’s work for him] since guilty should sign off on punishment, all executed punishment would be like a suicide > no law immune from interest, revenge, the sacrificial (for Kant, moral/judicial reason is sacrificial)

FWT.content: Kant’s interpretation of lex talionis, more Roman/Jewish than evangelical, applied to categorical imperative: “if you kill him, you kill yourself”
FWT.linkedContent: Kant’s interpretation of lex talionis, more Roman/Jewish than evangelical, applied to categorical imperative: “if you kill him, you kill yourself”

DPi.content: CI: immanent & pure calculation free of extrinsic calculation
DPi.linkedContent: CI: immanent & pure calculation free of extrinsic calculation

DPi.content: for Kant, justice finds itself here in double bind, knot: either honor (Ehrbegriff) is vain or DP should simply be set aside > Die Auflösung dieses Knotens: no more DP when law (CI) & nature align
DPi.linkedContent: for Kant, justice finds itself here in double bind, knot: either honor (Ehrbegriff) is vain or DP should simply be set aside > Die Auflösung dieses Knotens: no more DP when law (CI) & nature align

DPi.content: no more need to not DP women, they’ll never marry out of wedlock (Derrida adds: extraordinary & stupid uselessness, rigor & absurdity of Kant’s logic)
DPi.linkedContent: no more need to not DP women, they’ll never marry out of wedlock (Derrida adds: extraordinary & stupid uselessness, rigor & absurdity of Kant’s logic)

DPi.content: for Kant, CI, eye for an eye, talionic law, surpasses value of life and all price: no law will ever be founded on unconditional love of life (life for life’s sake)—on the absolute refusal of any sacrifice of life
DPi.linkedContent: for Kant, CI, eye for an eye, talionic law, surpasses value of life and all price: no law will ever be founded on unconditional love of life (life for life’s sake)—on the absolute refusal of any sacrifice of life

DPi.content: both abolitionists & Kant speak of price, value, dignity above Marketpries > for Kant, jus talionis is pure equivalence not revenge, impersonal principle of reparative justice
DPi.linkedContent: both abolitionists & Kant speak of price, value, dignity above Marketpries > for Kant, jus talionis is pure equivalence not revenge, impersonal principle of reparative justice

DPi.content: jus talionis: “categorical imperative” of penal justice, pure juridical rationality
DPi.linkedContent: jus talionis: “categorical imperative” of penal justice, pure juridical rationality

DPi.content: CI of DP, following Nietzsche & Baudelaire, is not pure disinterest, DP proponents afraid for themselves, interest in gaining release from torture (von ein Tortur loskommen), threat of verdict
DPi.linkedContent: CI of DP, following Nietzsche & Baudelaire, is not pure disinterest, DP proponents afraid for themselves, interest in gaining release from torture (von ein Tortur loskommen), threat of verdict

DPi.content: Nietzsche accuses Kant’s categorical imperative of a hypocritical cruelty, gives itself airs of keeping its hands clean (de n’y pas toucher)
DPi.linkedContent: Nietzsche accuses Kant’s categorical imperative of a hypocritical cruelty, gives itself airs of keeping its hands clean (de n’y pas toucher)

DPi.content: CI (and thus DP) is priceless, w/out interest, so Beccaria’s utilitarianism is not the law, is pathological; for Kant, justice can’t be evaluated, transcendent to calculation, to price of life, priceless > transcendence (maybe) of the “sur,” surviving beyond life (drive)
DPi.linkedContent: CI (and thus DP) is priceless, w/out interest, so Beccaria’s utilitarianism is not the law, is pathological; for Kant, justice can’t be evaluated, transcendent to calculation, to price of life, priceless > transcendence (maybe) of the “sur,” surviving beyond life (drive)

DPi.content: Kant: “the law of punishment is a categorical imperative”

HLP.content: for Kant, in Augustinian tradition, sacred duty, unconditional imperative not to lie; Schürmann: sacred, in Heidegger, keeps historical connotation, while awe and piety direct toward event, presencing (which is not at all historical)
HLP.linkedContent: for Kant, in Augustinian tradition, sacred duty, unconditional imperative not to lie; Schürmann: sacred, in Heidegger, keeps historical connotation, while awe and piety direct toward event, presencing (which is not at all historical)

HLP.content: Kant: veracity a formal duty (formale Pflicht)
for Kant, veracity as a formal condition of right, social contract, not ethical but meta-juridical, not historical: “[a lie] necessarily does harm to humanity in general”
HLP.linkedContent: for Kant, veracity as a formal condition of right, social contract, not ethical but meta-juridical, not historical: “[a lie] necessarily does harm to humanity in general”

HLP.content: Kant might say: “all language is structured by this promise of veracity,” “[when you lie] you cease speaking”; Derrida: difficult to refute unless one thinks specter of possible lie that haunts veracity
HLP.linkedContent: Kant might say: “all language is structured by this promise of veracity,” “[when you lie] you cease speaking”; Derrida: difficult to refute unless one thinks specter of possible lie that haunts veracity

HLP.content: rational law of sacred veracity: condition of history, human sociality
Kant: permit lying, destroy very possibility of promises
HLP.linkedContent: Kant: permit lying, destroy very possibility of promises

WAP.content: Kant’s maxim is not the law, it is the subjective relation to the law, rule of action in conformity w/ law > teaching/training thus administered at level of maxim
WAP.linkedContent: Kant’s maxim is not the law, it is the subjective relation to the law, rule of action in conformity w/ law > teaching/training thus administered at level of maxim

WAP.content: for Kant, right is only strict, not curved (krumm), oblique (schief), attains its proper stricture, in “contrainte réciproque universelle,” a link btwn universal and “freedom,” right has no internal depths (all internal can be exposed completely), its objects must be shown in actions, domain of visibility, theatricality w/out fold
WAP.linkedContent: for Kant, right is only strict, not curved (krumm), oblique (schief), attains its proper stricture, in “contrainte réciproque universelle,” a link btwn universal and “freedom,” right has no internal depths (all internal can be exposed completely), its objects must be shown in actions, domain of visibility, theatricality w/out fold

WAP.content: for Kant, foundation of right is not juridical but moral [Heideggerian gesture]
WAP.linkedContent: for Kant, foundation of right is not juridical but moral [Heideggerian gesture]

WAP.content: [tautological] consciousness of stricture [?]: being-right of right is its right to be right
WAP.linkedContent: [tautological] consciousness of stricture [?]: being-right of right is its right to be right

WAP.content: strict, narrow, rectilinear right must be perfectly external, can’t be motivated by consciousness of being before the law: right and external constraint are the same
WAP.linkedContent: strict, narrow, rectilinear right must be perfectly external, can’t be motivated by consciousness of being before the law: right and external constraint are the same

WAP.content: w/ rectilinearity & pedagogy what is at stake is the presentation (Darstellung) of a concept in a pure & a priori intuition, but following an analogy [w/ math] > only a perfectly external right deserves name of strict (narrow) right
WAP.linkedContent: w/ rectilinearity & pedagogy what is at stake is the presentation (Darstellung) of a concept in a pure & a priori intuition, but following an analogy [w/ math] > only a perfectly external right deserves name of strict (narrow) right

WAP.content: we assert our rights to the extent that we can, in a manner compatible w/ freedom of everyone > Kant: “right and the faculty of constraining are one and the same thing”
WAP.linkedContent: we assert our rights to the extent that we can, in a manner compatible w/ freedom of everyone > Kant: “right and the faculty of constraining are one and the same thing”

WAP.content: invitation (Aufforderung) to tribunal of reason would be a repetition of old task; Nancy on Critique: philosophy pronounces law on law
WAP.linkedContent: invitation (Aufforderung) to tribunal of reason would be a repetition of old task; Nancy on Critique: philosophy pronounces law on law

EL.content: [re: “we” of apocalyptic speech] responsibility is ineluctable, finds sign of its freedom in this fatality > not Kantian practical universality, formalizable obligation: does not replace itself, delegate itself
EL.linkedContent: [re: “we” of apocalyptic speech] responsibility is ineluctable, finds sign of its freedom in this fatality > not Kantian practical universality, formalizable obligation: does not replace itself, delegate itself

LI.content: speech act theory seeks the founding categories of all ethical-political statements: relation of intentionality to conventionality or to rules (in the best Kantian tradition)
LI.linkedContent: speech act theory seeks the founding categories of all ethical-political statements: relation of intentionality to conventionality or to rules (in the best Kantian tradition)

LI.content: unconditionality (Derrida intentionally recalling Kant’s CI) is independent of every determinate context, announces itself only in the opening of context
LI.linkedContent: unconditionality (Derrida intentionally recalling Kant’s CI) is independent of every determinate context, announces itself only in the opening of context

LI.content: unconditionality defines injunction that prescribes deconstruction: let another language, other thoughts, make their way
LI.linkedContent: unconditionality defines injunction that prescribes deconstruction: let another language, other thoughts, make their way

LI.content: Derrida hesitates to characterize all this in Kantian terms (though unconditionality intentionally recalls Kant’s CI) because those philosophemes call for deconstructive questions: he experiences a new responsibility, which he respects enough never to compromise
LI.linkedContent: Derrida hesitates to characterize all this in Kantian terms (though unconditionality intentionally recalls Kant’s CI) because those philosophemes call for deconstructive questions: he experiences a new responsibility, which he respects enough never to compromise

OG.content: transcendental signified: resource of sign, makes difference btwn signans/signatum absolute & irreducible > it is la voix s’entend: conscience, auto-affection (spontaneity, ideality, universality, non-mondain of substance)
OG.linkedContent: transcendental signified: resource of sign, makes difference btwn signans/signatum absolute & irreducible > it is la voix s’entend: conscience, auto-affection (spontaneity, ideality, universality, non-mondain of substance)

ATAP.content: acc. Kant, mystagogues confuse Geheimnis of practical reason w/ mystery of vision/contact > nothing more auto-affective than voice of moral law, not contaminated by feeling/illumination (touch/sight)
ATAP.linkedContent: acc. Kant, mystagogues confuse Geheimnis of practical reason w/ mystery of vision/contact > nothing more auto-affective than voice of moral law, not contaminated by feeling/illumination (touch/sight)

ATAP.content: don’t personify moral law, even as voice, that’s “pathological”: exclude any body, especially body of veiled Isis (aesthetic), universal principle of femininity
ATAP.linkedContent: don’t personify moral law, even as voice, that’s “pathological”: exclude any body, especially body of veiled Isis (aesthetic), universal principle of femininity

EU.content: moral law, object of the greatest respect (der grössten Achtung), adoration addressed to Supreme Cause (Ursache) > thus Kant explains legitimacy/necessity of censorship
EU.linkedContent: moral law, object of the greatest respect (der grössten Achtung), adoration addressed to Supreme Cause (Ursache) > thus Kant explains legitimacy/necessity of censorship

EU.content: highest form of pure reason—pure practical reason, pure laws of practical reason should constrain in a respect given freely
EU.linkedContent: highest form of pure reason—pure practical reason, pure laws of practical reason should constrain in a respect given freely

EU.content: since finitude of man degrades moral law’s sublimity, respect for it (form of censorship) must be posed from outside, by “coercive laws”  > thus, there would be no university w/out principle of evil in man [Derrida remarks that this statement isn’t false, but is formulated too quickly]
EU.linkedContent: since finitude of man degrades moral law’s sublimity, respect for it (form of censorship) must be posed from outside, by “coercive laws” > thus, there would be no university w/out principle of evil in man [Derrida remarks that this statement isn’t false, but is formulated too quickly]

EU.content: Kant’s politics always re: State reason as a censoring reason > for Kant, censorship: a critique that has force (Gewalt) at its disposal—pure force does not censor [?]
EU.linkedContent: Kant’s politics always re: State reason as a censoring reason > for Kant, censorship: a critique that has force (Gewalt) at its disposal—pure force does not censor [?]

EU.content: Kant’s The Conflict of the Faculties: a dictionary or grammar, powerful effort to formalize Western university (which is finished, marked by finitude)
EU.linkedContent: Kant’s The Conflict of the Faculties: a dictionary or grammar, powerful effort to formalize Western university (which is finished, marked by finitude)

EU.content: formal law: pure legitimation, reason as court of final appeal > pure ethico-juridical instance, tautology, pure practical reason, decision of pure egological subject
EU.linkedContent: formal law: pure legitimation, reason as court of final appeal > pure ethico-juridical instance, tautology, pure practical reason, decision of pure egological subject

EU.content: Kant’s “heroic” effort to mark off juridical borders btwn 2 classes of [university] faculties > freedom of judgment, philosophy, the unconditioned condition w/out which there is no university
EU.linkedContent: Kant’s “heroic” effort to mark off juridical borders btwn 2 classes of [university] faculties > freedom of judgment, philosophy, the unconditioned condition w/out which there is no university

EU.content: metaphysics of morals deals w/ freedom not nature, rights & duty, to possess metaphysics is a duty > everyone has this metaphysics and thus this duty—a Faktum ——for Kant, metaphysics: a priori system of knowledge by simple concepts
EU.linkedContent: metaphysics of morals deals w/ freedom not nature, rights & duty, to possess metaphysics is a duty > everyone has this metaphysics and thus this duty—a Faktum ——for Kant, metaphysics: a priori system of knowledge by simple concepts
